facts.text: Petition is Original Jurisdiction Petition No. 98 of 1956 under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 98 of 1956. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on May 8, 1957 by GOVINDA MENON, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. May 8. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GOVINDA MENON, J.-This application under Art. 32 of the Constitution raises the question of the companystitutionality of s. 178-A, inserted in the Sea Customs Act,  VIII of 1878 , by s. 14 of the Amending Act XXI of 1955,

facts.text: Petitioner carries on business as a broker in diamonds and precious stones in Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner carries on business as a broker in diamonds and precious stones in Calcutta and, according to him, he enjoys credit and reputation in the market as a well-known and respectable broker of such goods.

facts.text: On May 4, 1955, Rummaging Inspector Intelligence, Customs House, Calcutta (Respondent No. 3) searched petitioner's residential room at No. 32, Sir Hariram Goenka Street, Calcutta with search warrant from Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta (Respondent No. 4).

anchor.surface_text: On May 4, 1955, the Rummaging Inspector  Intelligence , Customs House, Calcutta, Respondent No. 3, armed with a search warrant from the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta, Respondent No. 4, searched the residential room of the petitioner, situated at No. 32, Sir Hariram Goenka Street, Calcutta,

facts.text: Steel almirah searched, petitioner denied having diamonds.

anchor.surface_text: and after a minute search of the steel almirah in which according to the statement of the petitioner, he used to keep his stock in trade and finding numbere there questioned him as to where he had secreted the diamonds to which the 1112 reply given by him was in the negative.

facts.text: 475 pieces of diamonds and one piece of synthetic stone discovered in old jacket in wall almirah.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon a wall almirah, wherein washed clothes, and other articles were stored, was searched and therein in an old jacket 475 pieces of diamonds were discovered along with one piece of synthetic stone.

facts.text: Petitioner's statement: Rs. 10,000 worth of diamonds received from M/s. Ratilal Amritlal of 89 Zaveri Bazar, Bombay; rest purchased locally without records.

anchor.surface_text: A statement signed by him was taken from which we find that his explanation for the possession was that Rs. 10,000/- worth of diamonds were received by him from M s. Ratilal Amritlal, of 89 Zaveri Bazar, Bombay, and the rest were purchased locally in Calcutta. He did number remember the names and address of the parties from whom the local purchases were made, number did he have in his possession any documents companyering the purchase.

facts.text: Petitioner escorted to Customs House; Assistant Collector gave time till May 7, 1955 to produce evidence of legal import.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Rummaging Inspector escorted the petitioner to the Customs House where the Assistant Collector, Customs, asked him to produce evidence showing that the goods were number smuggled goods but were legally imported on payment of duty. The Assistant Collector then permitted the petitioner to go and gave him time till May 7, 1955,

facts.text: Notice served on petitioner on May 4, 1955 by Customs authorities requiring documents by May 7, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: to produce evidence showing that the goods were imported on payment of customs duty and under a valid import licence. On the same day, i.e., May 4, 1955, a numberice was served on the petitioner by the Customs authorities stating that there were reasonable grounds to believe that the goods seized by the Rummaging Inspector had been illegally imported into India

facts.text: Advocates for petitioner wrote to Assistant Collector on May 7, 1955 requesting reasons for seizure and more time.

anchor.surface_text: In answer to this, on behalf of the petitioner Messrs. S. K. Sawday and Company, a firm of Advocates, Calcutta, wrote to the Assistant Collector, Customs, on May 7, 1955, reciting the circumstances under which the petitioner came to 1113 be in possession of the seized articles alleging that in the circumstances the presumption of an offence

facts.text: Further letters from petitioner's advocates on May 9, 1955; May 16, 1955; enclosing certificates.

anchor.surface_text: Another letter was written by the same firm of Advocates on May 9, 1955, the details of which it is unnecessary to refer. On May 16, 1955, a further letter was written enclosing two certificates and companytaining further particulars. This also reiterated the request for the supply of specific reasons for the seizure.

facts.text: Assistant Collector replied on May 23, 1955 that diamonds seized on reasonable suspicion of illegal import.

anchor.surface_text: On May 23, 1955, the Assistant Collector replied to the Advocates informing them that the diamonds in question were seized on reasonable suspicions that the same had been imported into India illegally and as such were liable to seizure under the Sea Customs Act.

facts.text: Correspondence continued: June 20, 1955; June 25, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Further companyrespondence followed by a letter dated June 20, 1955, to which there was a reply on June 25, 1955, wherein there was a detailed reference to everything that had taken place till then and especially with regard to the earlier denial of the petitioner

facts.text: Letters from petitioner's advocates on July 1, July 4, July 20, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On July 1, 1955, Messrs. K. Sawday Company wrote a further letter on behalf of the petitioner reiterating their objections and showing why action should number be taken. This was followed by letters dated July 4 and 20, 1955.

facts.text: Personal hearing granted on July 21, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: A personal hearing was granted on July 21, 1955, followed by a letter from the Advocates 1114 dated July 22, 1955.

facts.text: Collector of Customs passed order on September 12, 1955, dispatched November 5, 1955, confiscating diamonds under ss. 167(8) and 167(39), finding presumption under s. 178-A not rebutted.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector of Customs thereupon, after companysidering the entire matter placed before him, passed an order dated September 12, 1955, which was dispatched on November 5, 1955, companytaining an elaborate discussion of the various facts and circumstances and finally companycluding that since the petitioner had failed to discharge the onus under s. 178-A of the Sea Customs Act in respect of the diamonds seized on May 4, 1955, orders had been passed companyfiscating the same under ss. 167  8  and 167  39  of the Sea Customs Act

facts.text: Petitioner did not appeal to Central Board of Revenue but filed Art. 32 petition in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Without availing himself of that remedy the petitioner has companye up to this Court by way of an application for a writ under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Section 178-A inserted by s. 14 of Amending Act XXI of 1955 in Sea Customs Act, 1878.

anchor.surface_text: This application under Art. 32 of the Constitution raises the question of the companystitutionality of s. 178-A, inserted in the Sea Customs Act,  VIII of 1878 , by s. 14 of the Amending Act XXI of 1955, and the chief ground on which it is sought to be struck down is that it offends Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Goods seized: 475 diamonds liable under s. 178-A as diamonds are specified.

anchor.surface_text: Section 178-A applies to diamonds and other precious stones and there has been numberdispute about 1119 the application of this provision to the present case.

facts.text: Court finds s. 178-A constitutional, not violating Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned section cannot be struck down on the infirmity either of discrimination or illegal classification. Confining as it does to certain classes of goods seized by the customs authorities on the reasonable belief that they are smuggled goods, there is only a presumption which can be rebutted.

facts.text: Seizure made in reasonable belief that goods are smuggled.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts mentioned above it is clear that the seizure has been under the Act in the reasonable belief of the Customs authorities that they are smuggled goods and, therefore, the burden of proving that they are number smuggled goods has been cast by this section on the persons from whose possession the goods are seized.

facts.text: Petitioner's initial denial of diamonds contradicted later explanation.

anchor.surface_text: especially with regard to the earlier denial of the petitioner about there being any diamonds with him and the discovery of the same later on in a used jacket in a wall almirah.

facts.text: Collector noted attempt to hide diamonds suspiciously.

anchor.surface_text: The reasons given in the above order were that the subsequent statements were companytrary to what had been stated in the first instance, that at the time of the raid, an attempt was made to hide the diamonds in a suspicious manner

facts.text: Appeal lay to Central Board of Revenue within 3 months of dispatch.

anchor.surface_text: The order stated that an appeal against it lay to the Central Board of Revenue within three months of the date of the dispatch and also companytained information as to the companyrt-fee stamps etc., which would have to be affixed.

Section 178-A applies to diamonds... On the facts mentioned above it is clear that the seizure has been under the Act in the reasonable belief of the Customs authorities that they are smuggled goods

holdings.text: The impugned section cannot be struck down on the infirmity either of discrimination or illegal classification. Confining as it does to certain classes of goods seized by the customs authorities on the reasonable belief that they are smuggled goods, there is only a presumption which can be rebutted. In these circumstances, there can be no doubt whatever that s. 178-A does not offend Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned section cannot be struck down on the infirmity either of discrimination or illegal classification. Confining as it does to certain classes of goods seized by the customs authorities on the reasonable belief that they are smuggled goods, there is only a presumption which can be rebutted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Art.14 reasonable classification test from precedents: intelligible differentia in goods easily smuggled and seized on reasonable belief has rational nexus to preventing smuggling; rebuttable presumption avoids arbitrariness.

holdings.text: A cursory perusal of s. 178-A will at once disclose the well defined classification of goods based on an intelligible differentia. It applies only to certain goods described in sub-s. (2) which are or can be easily smuggled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis shows classification limited to specified easily smuggable goods seized under Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation links classification and presumption directly to Act's anti-smuggling objective.

holdings.text: On the facts mentioned above it is clear that the seizure has been under the Act in the reasonable belief of the Customs authorities that they are smuggled goods and, therefore, the burden of proving that they are not smuggled goods has been cast by this section on the persons from whose possession the goods are seized.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts mentioned above it is clear that the seizure has been under the Act in the reasonable belief of the Customs authorities that they are smuggled goods and, therefore, the burden of proving that they are not smuggled goods has been cast by this section on the persons from whose possession the goods are seized.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts of search, initial denial, suspicious concealment establish reasonable belief triggering statutory presumption and burden shift.

holdings.text: It is now well established that while Art. 14 forbids class legislation, it does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. In order, however, to pass the test of permissible classification two conditions must be fulfilled, namely (1) that the classification must be founded on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group and, (2) that that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute in question.

anchor.surface_text: It is now well established that while Art. 14 forbids class legislation, it does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. anchor.surface_text: A cursory perusal of s. 178-A will at once disclose the well defined classification of goods based on an intelligible differentia. It applies only to certain goods described in sub-s. (2) which are or can be easily smuggled. The, section applies only to those goods of the specified kind which have been seized under the Act and in the reasonable belief that they are smuggled goods. It is only those goods which answer the threefold description that companye under the operation of the section. The object of the Act is to prevent smuggling. The differentia on the basis. of which the goods have been classified and the presumption raised by the section obviously have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the Act.

outcome.relief_summary: Constitutionality of s. 178-A upheld; does not violate Art. 14

anchor.surface_text: The impugned section cannot be struck down on the infirmity either of discrimination or illegal classification. Confining as it does to certain classes of goods seized by the customs authorities on the reasonable belief that they are smuggled goods, there is only a presumption which can be rebutted.

edges.explanation: Holding rejecting discrimination infirmity addresses issue of Art.14 equal protection violation.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts mentioned above it is clear that the seizure has been under the Act in the reasonable belief of the Customs authorities that they are smuggled goods and, therefore, the burden of proving that they are not smuggled goods has been cast by this section on the persons from whose possession the goods are seized.
